Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Stream Consumers and Lotic Ecosystem Rates (SCALER): Scaling from Centimeters to Continents
Award.AbstractNarration: The overarching question that Scale, Consumers and Lotic Ecosystem Rates (SCALER) will address is: How can small-scale ecological experiments be applied to understand the behavior of entire ecological systems? Funds are provided to address:: 1) How should measures of fundamental properties of streams and effects of animals on those properties be scaled up to predict ecosystem characteristics of stream networks. 2) How do patterns of scaling compare across the wide array of ecological systems (from tundra to tropical forest) that occurs across North American? The SCALER experiment will be done in tropical forest, temperate mountainous forest, prairie, northern boreal evergreen forest, and tundra areas. Streams in each of these five areas will be examined at scales of centimeters to 10?s of meters in small, medium and large streams. Rates of stream metabolism (photosynthesis and respiration) and nutrient uptake will be measured as well as the way these rates respond to animal exclusions (used to mimic loss of animal diversity in streams). These local results will be linked to the scale of watersheds and regions by modeling. Watershed scale predictions will be verified by broader, but less intensive sampling. Mechanistic explanation of how ecological measurements and experiments in streams can be scaled to watersheds will be provided. This scaling will be characterized in each of the five areas across the continent to explore how scaling differs across natural habitats. The knowledge that will be generated by this project is essential to quantify controls on stream ecosystem processes as well as to manage human impacts on entire watersheds. The experimental and modeling results will be relevant to general ecology because few nested, and experimental and theoretically coupled scaling experiments have been undertaken in any environment. Results will inform those involved in conservation, management, and restoration of freshwater resources. Resource managers will gain a quantitative rationale and framework to link local measurements to regional patterns. The highly collaborative team will train six graduate students, five post doctoral students, and mentor three early career faculty members. Additional collaborations will be encouraged to collaborate and perform similar projects at additional sites through workshops related to the objectives and research design.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Arctic is a part of the world that few people have visited or understand. However, increasingly, a wider portion of the public is realizing that there are important connections between the Arctic and the global environment, which could have real impacts at a local level; e.g., sea level rise and expanded growing seasons. Understanding these connections is essential for future management and policy decisions. The Scale, Consumers and Lotic Ecosystem Rates (SCALER) project was a continental-scale experiment designed to address a simple but fundamentally complex question. Specifically: What is the best way to use measurements that are typically taken at very local (small) scales and expand them to regional and continental scales that are of most interest to policy makers and resource managers?  This is a question that is of direct interest to the National Environmental Observatory Network (NEON) and to the general science and management communities.

 

The Arctic component of the SCALER project was one of five collaborative projects distributed strategically across the United States to capture a broad suite of environmental conditions from Arctic, through Temperate, to Tropical biomes. At each SCALER research site, we established six experimental stream reaches (sites) with measurements nested at two scales (microhabitat, reach), linked to watershed models. Extensive (synoptic) sampling at each site was used to characterize watershed-scale patterns of nutrients in stream networks at particular moments in time. Intensive measurements of metabolism, nutrient uptake, and responses to consumer exclusion were measured over longer periods of time at each site in each biome.

 As a consequence of this Arctic-specific project we have a better understanding of the range of variability in critical ecosystem characteristics of headwater streams in the Tundra biome. Our efforts to capture the "state" of entire stream networks at particular moments in time (via synoptic sampling) has revealed patterns in solute concentrations (e.g., nitrate and dissolved organic carbon) that help us interpret how landscape factors (presence of lakes, land cover, land disturbance) influence patterns of nutrient availability across this landscape and potentially influence ecosystem processes (e.g., stream metabolism and nutrient uptake) as well as the distributions of organisms that live in these streams.

We also did experiments to explore relationships between the size of particles (i.e., gravel, pebbles, and cobbles) and fundamental ecosystem processes (specifically, stream metabolism and nutrient uptake). Our experiments revealed that when rates are expressed in terms of two-dimensional area on the bottom of the stream (planar basis), the rates decrease strongly as particle size increases.  But when expressed in terms of the actual surface area of the rocks under the same planar area (surface area basis), the rates increase slightly with particle size. This suggests that these important ecosystem rates may be distributed fairly evenly on particle surfaces. However, because particles of different sizes have different surface areas, rates expressed on a planar basis may differ. The planar basis is the approach utilized almost universally in stream ecology. Our results show that a substantial portion of the variance typically observed in these experiments may be due to differences in particle sizes.

Our efforts to understand the physical, chemical and functional responses of streams in the Arctic provided a unique opportunity to quantify macroinvertebrate biodiversity at various scales within a watershed. We paired sub-watersheds that were characterized by many lakes with those that had no lakes within the greater Oksrukuyik Creek watershed to increase our understanding of the factors that influence biodiversity at various scales. Our results showed that macroinvertebrate biodiversity is influenced by habitat heterogeneity at scales larger than expected and that efforts to quantify maximum biodiversity would be grossly underestimated if efforts did not include a variety of mesoscale (100m-1000m) habitats, even when the types of habitats that the samples are collected from are identical in other aspects.

 As a consequence of our interactions with other collaborators on this SCALER project we have been able to contribute to broader syntheses from this continent-wide project. For instance, we noted that conditions at or near typical, low flow conditions (baseflow) are important for most ecologically relevant processes like metabolism and nutrient uptake.  At higher flows, these processes are less important.  However, it is these higher flows (specifically bankfull flows) that are the focus of research on stream geomorphology.  Thus, there is a disconnect when trying to link stream ecological processes to stream geomorphological processes.  We demonstrated that some factors (e.g., stream baseflow width and canopy cover) could be related to upstream basin area (a geomorphological driving variable), but that other variables (e.g., sediment particle size) could not.

 The results of our research suggest that stream geomorphic theory can be combined with relatively simple statistical models to estimate fundamental stream ecosystem processes like metabolism and stream uptake. This could be an important conceptualization to include in landscape-scale models that explicitly include stream ecosystem processing.
